captions.text:
The principle of max-strength training is
to increase the strength of the muscle which
also increases its power capacity.

Within our pre-season it's our development
stage and we can actually put them through

an overload, more volume in the gym. High
reps, higher sets with added load and added resistance.
Nice, then drop it down. Spot on mate.

Generally within our strength sessions we're
doing three of four sets working up to five rep max.

So our first principle exercise in our programme
is the trap bar deadlift.

As we grab it we lower into it, sit our hips
back, chest nice and big, explosive up. Knock
it down, straight back up. For five reps.

Today's principle lift was trap bar so predominantly
working the hamstring eccentric and concentric

contractions can be replicated on the pitch
in terms of running, so what we're working

around is the principles of that functional
movement but actually isolating it within the gym.

A professional athlete should be able to lift
two times his bodyweight within a deadlift.

That strength should hopefully ensure that
the hamstring doesn't tear and cause an injury.

Next exercise is split squat foot raise using
the bench. Take the front foot forward, and

then all you're doing is going down making
sure that comes to a ninety degree or just

below ninety and this one should nearly touch
the floor.

Football isn't played in a bilateral plane,
so that means two feet stood together like
we saw with the trap bar.

Try and drive the heel into the ground as
well.

Football is multi-directional so you might
bound off one leg and change direction, that

single leg squat is working the quadracep
mainly but also hamstring stabilization and

glute, they're the main functional areas we
use within a game, within our training creating
that platform of injury prevention and strengthening.

Next exercise is wide grip pull up. Pull ups
are great upper body exercise. It utilizes

core body stabilization, delts, traps, latts
everything is activated within the back, upper

body strength is just as important as lower
body strength within football. If you're challenging

with an opponent you can shrug them off and
keep your core stablized to change direction

or when you're dribbling with the ball. It's
not about muscle depth, it's about muscle

quality. These exercises can be replicated
anywhere, we're blessed with the facilities

we've got. But you don't necessarily need
the high-modern fashion racks to set up a

nice strength session. The modern game has
become so physically demanding, players now

you're seeing are taller, faster, stronger.
You need to make sure you focus on your gym

work make sure you focus on your pitch work
and don't slack on any of them. Strength is

one of the essential principles you want to
include in your game, get into the gym, work

hard, train hard and hopefully you get that
pro.

comments.text: And u wonder why soccer player r so skinny and soft...hahahaha ﻿
comments.author: Tina Po'uha

comments.text:
+Tina Po'uha They have to be built similar to middle distance runners, 
endurance is vital as a soccer player. 

Elite footballers will cover over 5 miles (8km) in a 90 minute match, their 
body fat percentages are below 10% and skill in soccer is a lot more 
important than explosive power unlike the NFL. 

There is no point running under 11 seconds In football, jumping 36 inches 
and being able to rep 225x15 reps if you have no skill, get injured all the 
time and can't last 10 minutes on the field.

Generally, I've never really seen elite footballers over 14 stone on the 
field, and if they are they are normally 6"4+ The average footballer is 
around 11 1/2 stone

comments.author: Scott Anderson

comments.text:
I beg to differ about strength as in Football it is not necessary to become 
a great player a prime example of that is Messi he's not strong and he's 
not tall but he's mastered the game he's a complete artist in the sense of 
the word. yes if his physical stature was greater it would be beneficial 
but he has the technique to still beat bigger quicker stronger defenders.﻿
comments.author: Cristiano Ronaldo

comments.text:
Yes that is correct but if you stuck Messi in defence he probably wouldn't 
fare to well because in that position you would want someone with a lot of 
strength, so the Nike Academy thought that if all of out players had high 
strength levels they will be able to compete with the very physical sides.
comments.author: DMRcrazy23

comments.text:
I would beg to differ... Messi is indeed strong, a prime example of this is 
him receiving human growth hormone injections at a young age.  Speed, which 
Messi has in abundance, is largely a result of mass specific force and is 
developed with exercises like ones in this video.  Look also at his 
balance, a function of core strength. Are you saying these trainers don't 
know what they are doing?  It is called sports science, not sports 
pseudo-science.  I agree with Ash NK, most clubs who are serious about 
winning do strength training as part of there comprehensive and scientific 
approach to soccer fitness.
comments.author: Daniel Miranda

comments.text: +Ash NK  Naymar Too...
comments.author: Raushan Sinha

comments.text:
Strength is not everything. But if you think Lionel Messi does not do any 
upper body strength training, then you are wrong. The biggest clubs do gym 
work, not bodybuilding gym work, but strength training.

comments.author: love4music8

comments.text:
Ok this is all well and good... but isn't this what's fundamentally wring 
with the English game?
Too much emphasis on strength and power rather than honing players natural 
ability. The England players are fantastic athletes and yes they can run 
for days but in terms of natural ability they're below par when it comes to 
the world's elite. 
Saying the world's best are now taller, stronger and faster isn't totally 
true. To be fair the only elite players who I can think of who fit that 
exact criteria are Bale and Ronaldo maybe Robben (not sure if you class him 
as 'tall') ﻿
